context: Catalase is an antioxidant enzyme that protects the cells against increases in hydrogen peroxide levels produced by the cell during normal and perturbed conditions (Makino et al., 1994, 1995; Masaki et al., 1998). Decreases in catalase activity have been identified in disease, aging and exposure to chemicals and UV light (Lu et al., 1999; Yan et al., 1999; Alam et al., 2000; Sander et al., 2002). In the present study, m-xylene exposure led to a time- and dose-dependent decrease in endogenous catalase in dermal fibroblasts that occurred with decreasing cell viability. The addition of catalase during m-xylene exposure appeared to provide marginal protection against cytotoxicity, since we observed that the presence of catalase promoted a non-significant increase in cell viability at 1 h with no effect on cell viability at 4 h. These results suggest that catalase may be providing little protection against m-xylene-induced cytotoxicity. Oxidative stress produced following exposure to the free radical-generating stimuli, such as UV light, silica and 3-morpholinosydnonimine-N-ethylcarbamide, contributes to cytotoxicity in dermal fibroblasts (Masaki and Sakurai, 1997; Lomonosova et al., 1998; Cho et al., 1999). This cytotoxicity can be partially inhibited by the addition of catalase during exposure of the fibroblasts.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 1,3-xylene exposure is linked to decreased cell survival in dermal fibroblasts, as indicated by a time- and dose-dependent reduction in catalase activity, which is an antioxidant enzyme. The study suggests that while the addition of catalase may provide some marginal protection against cytotoxicity induced by 1,3-xylene, it does not significantly improve cell viability over time. This indicates a detrimental effect of 1,3-xylene on cell survival, likely through mechanisms involving oxidative stress.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 4 reflects a significant connection between 1,3-xylene and cell survival, as the study provides evidence of decreased cell viability associated with xylene exposure and discusses the role of catalase in this context. The relationship is supported by experimental data, although the protective effect of catalase is limited.
